Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.cause: Caused by the bacterium *Xanthomonas campestris*, which thrives in warm, wet conditions and spreads through splashing water, tools, and infected plant material.
remedies: Apply copper-based bactericides regularly to inhibit bacterial growth.
Avoid overhead irrigation which facilitates bacterial spread via water droplets.
Practice crop rotation and immediately remove infected plants to reduce inoculum levels.
prevention: Start with certified disease-free seeds to prevent initial contamination.
Maintain strict field hygiene including sanitized tools and clean equipment.
Refrain from handling plants when wet to prevent spreading bacteria.
Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.crop_care: Ensure adequate spacing between plants to promote airflow, reduce humidity, and perform regular inspections for early symptoms.

Pepper__bell___healthy.cause: No disease present in the plant.
Pepper__bell___healthy.crop_care: Maintain optimal soil fertility, consistent watering, proper sunlight exposure, and monitor regularly for pests or abnormalities.

Potato___Early_blight.cause: A fungal disease caused by *Alternaria solani* that affects older leaves, creating concentric rings and eventually causing defoliation.
remedies: Use fungicides such as mancozeb, chlorothalonil, or azoxystrobin as per recommended guidelines.
Promptly remove infected leaves to limit disease spread.
Ensure adequate spacing between plants to improve airflow and reduce humidity.
prevention: Practice 2â€“3 year crop rotation to break the disease cycle.
Select early blight-resistant potato varieties whenever possible.
Avoid irrigation late in the day to minimize leaf wetness duration.
Potato___Early_blight.crop_care: Use organic mulch around the base of the plants to prevent soil-borne spores from splashing onto leaves.

Potato___healthy.crop_care: Ensure consistent watering schedules, monitor for pests like aphids and beetles, and maintain proper soil drainage and nutrient levels.

Potato___Late_blight.cause: Caused by *Phytophthora infestans*, a fast-spreading fungus-like organism that thrives in cool, moist environments and can decimate crops rapidly.
remedies: Begin preventative fungicide sprays during early stages of crop growth.
Immediately uproot and destroy any infected plants to prevent rapid spread.
Avoid overhead irrigation to minimize leaf wetness and spore dispersal.
prevention: Plant only certified, disease-free seed potatoes.
Avoid planting in fields previously affected by late blight.
Ensure proper field drainage and avoid dense planting.
Potato___Late_blight.crop_care: Use raised beds or ridges to improve water runoff and avoid soil saturation around plant roots.

Tomato_Target_Spot.cause: Caused by the fungus *Corynespora cassiicola*, which produces target-like lesions on leaves and can lead to premature defoliation in humid conditions.
remedies: Apply fungicides like azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil at early signs of infection.
Ensure wide spacing between plants to improve air circulation.
Remove and destroy affected foliage promptly.
prevention: Avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity around foliage.
Rotate crops with non-host plants every season.
Tomato_Target_Spot.crop_care: Clean debris and weeds in the field regularly and maintain soil moisture without excess.

Tomato_Tomato_mosaic_virus.cause: A viral disease caused by Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV), which spreads through contaminated tools, hands, and infected plant materials.
remedies: Remove and destroy all symptomatic plants to prevent further spread.
Sanitize tools and equipment frequently.
Manage insect vectors such as aphids and whiteflies using safe insecticides.
prevention: Use resistant or tolerant tomato varieties.
Wash hands thoroughly and disinfect tools before and after working in fields.
Tomato_Tomato_mosaic_virus.crop_care: Avoid handling plants when wet and maintain optimal growing conditions to reduce plant stress.

Tomato_Tomato_YellowLeaf_Curl_Virus.cause: Caused by TYLCV and transmitted mainly by whiteflies, leading to stunted growth, leaf curling, and yellowing.
remedies: Apply recommended insecticides to control whitefly populations.
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately upon detection.
Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and reduce whitefly presence.
prevention: Plant TYLCV-resistant varieties.
Use floating row covers early in the season to prevent vector access.
Tomato_Tomato_YellowLeaf_Curl_Virus.crop_care: Keep the field weed-free as many weeds act as alternate hosts for whiteflies.

Tomato_Bacterial_spot.cause: Caused by *Xanthomonas* spp., this disease affects leaves, stems, and fruit, particularly under warm and wet conditions.
remedies: Spray copper-based bactericides during early plant stages.
Avoid handling or pruning plants when they are wet.
Remove and destroy infected plant parts to limit spread.
prevention: Use only certified and treated seeds.
Avoid splashing irrigation water directly on foliage.
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.crop_care: Ensure adequate plant spacing and regularly prune to improve airflow and reduce moisture buildup.

Tomato_Early_blight.cause: Caused by *Alternaria solani*, a fungus that produces dark, concentric lesions on leaves and stems, often starting from the lower foliage.
remedies: Use preventive fungicides at regular intervals.
Immediately remove affected foliage to prevent spore spread.
Avoid overhead watering and irrigate at the base.
prevention: Cultivate resistant tomato varieties.
Implement crop rotation practices and avoid nightshades for successive years.
Tomato_Early_blight.crop_care: Control weeds, maintain good air circulation, and reduce leaf wetness through mulching.

Tomato_healthy.crop_care: Ensure balanced fertilization, regular irrigation, pest monitoring, and timely pruning for overall plant vigor.

Tomato_Late_blight.cause: Caused by *Phytophthora infestans*, this disease spreads rapidly in humid conditions, causing dark lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits.
remedies: Use fungicides preventively, particularly during wet seasons.
Uproot and destroy affected plants immediately.
Improve air circulation and avoid dense planting.
prevention: Avoid using infected seeds or planting material.
Choose well-drained and sun-exposed planting sites.
Tomato_Late_blight.crop_care: Apply mulch to reduce soil splash, monitor daily for symptoms, and prune lower leaves to prevent contact with soil.

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.cause: A fungal infection caused by *Fulvia fulva*, it typically affects tomatoes in high humidity environments, producing yellow spots on upper leaves and mold on the undersides.
remedies: Improve air movement using fans or spacing.
Apply sulfur-based or copper fungicides.
Prune and remove lower or infected leaves.
prevention: Irrigate at the base and avoid wetting foliage.
Keep greenhouse humidity levels below 85%.
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.crop_care: Sanitize greenhouse structures and avoid overcrowding to prevent fungal buildup.

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.cause: Caused by the fungus *Septoria lycopersici*, characterized by small, circular spots with dark margins on older leaves.
remedies: Apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or mancozeb.
Destroy infected debris to reduce overwintering inoculum.
Rotate crops and avoid overhead irrigation.
prevention: Use mulch to reduce soil splashing.
Prune lower leaves and ensure proper spacing.
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.crop_care: Irrigate early in the day, keep fields clean, and practice crop sanitation regularly.

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.cause: Infestation by *Tetranychus urticae*, tiny arachnids that feed on plant sap, causing yellowing and stippling on leaves.
remedies: Apply miticides or neem oil to control infestations.
Increase humidity which reduces mite reproduction.
Use strong water spray to dislodge mites from leaves.
prevention: Routinely inspect the undersides of leaves for mites or webbing.
Avoid plant water stress and maintain healthy foliage.
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.crop_care: Encourage natural predators such as ladybugs and predatory mites for biological control.
